summary.text: Scalars have magnitude only (speed, distance, time). Vectors have magnitude AND direction (velocity, displacement, acceleration, force).

importance.text: Direction changes everything. Moving 5m east then 5m west gives you 10m distance (scalar) but 0m displacement (vector). Speed tells you how fast; velocity tells you how fast AND where.

explanations.text: Because physics happens in 3D space. Things don't just have amounts—they point somewhere. Force without direction is meaningless.
Space has no preferred direction. Up isn't special. Every direction is equivalent, so we need to specify which way we mean.
Because change requires comparison. Motion is change in position relative to something else. Relativity demands we specify direction.
No absolute positions = must specify direction.

options.explanation: Temperature is a scalar quantity because it only has magnitude, no directional component.
Mass is a scalar quantity representing the amount of matter, with no associated direction.
Momentum is a vector quantity because it includes both magnitude (15 kg⋅m/s) and direction (east).
Kinetic energy is a scalar quantity - it represents the energy of motion without directional information.

feedback.correct: Correct! Momentum has both magnitude and direction, making it a vector.
feedback.incorrect: Think about which quantity includes direction information.
feedback.explanation: Only momentum includes a direction (east), making it a vector. All other options are scalars with magnitude only.
